title: Lightning bolt splits a tree in two narrowly missing a school in Texas
title_page: Lightning bolt splits a tree in two narrowly missing a school in Texas | Daily Mail Online
text:
No one was hurt by the lightning strike last week
Tree in school's prayer garden destroyed and phone lines were damaged
This is the shocking moment a huge bolt of lightning struck a tree in Texas, splitting it in two in a blinding flash of light.
Sparks fly off the tree as the lightning rod crashes down, slicing the trunk down the middle and sending branches flying.
The ferocious force of nature came smashing down just yards from Bishop Thomas K. Gorman Catholic School in Tyler, Texas, last week.

The tree, which is behind the parking lot of the school, was almost completely annihilated by the lightning bolt.
Most of the tree's upper branches plunged to the earth after the 1billion-volt strike, but luckily they avoided falling onto parked cars.
A puff of smoke can be seen to the right of the tree. This is where the lightning exited the ground and is likely to be near where the tree's roots end.
Unsurprisingly, teachers and students heard a huge bang as the lightning struck, as well as the sound of the tree collapsing.

Alongside a picture of what was left of the tree, the school tweeted: 'Phones out temporarily due to lightning strike. Tree down in the prayer garden. All students and staff are fine.'
Mark Scirto, chief meteorologist at KLTV-7, said the lightning strike on January 22 was 'one of the awesome powers of nature'.
He wrote on Facebook: 'Shortly after 9:35 yesterday morning, right after the kids made it to class safely, lightning struck the big tree.
